Example

Solve the following simultaneous equations by finding the inverse of the appropriate matrix, \[ \begin{align*} &3x + 2y = 7 \\ &5x - y = 3 \end{align*} \]

Solution

Note that we can write these simultaneous equations in terms of matrices as \[ \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 5 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}, \] we can multiply these matrices to check this is the correct matrix form of the equations. In order to solve this we therefore have to obtain the inverse of the matrix \[ A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 5 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \] then multiply the equations on the left by this inverse. So using the formula for the inverse of a \(2 \times 2\) matrix we obtain \[ A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{1}{13} & \frac{2}{13} \\ \frac{5}{13} & -\frac{3}{13} \end{bmatrix}. \] Hence multiplying the matrix equation above on the left we have \[ A^{-1}A \mathbf{x} = A^{-1}\mathbf{b} \implies \mathbf{x} = A^{-1}\mathbf{b} \implies \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{1}{13} & \frac{2}{13} \\ \frac{5}{13} & -\frac{3}{13} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}. \] Performing this matrix multiplication we obtain the values for \(\mathbf{x}\): \[ \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}. \] In other words, the solution to our simultaneous equations is \(x = 1, y = 2\).


Why don't we solve these equations by substitution to check the answers? Rearrange the second equation to get \(y = 5x-3\) substituting this into the first equation we get \[ 3x + 2(5x-3) = 3x + 10x - 6 = 7 \implies 13x = 13 \implies x=1. \] Substituting this into the second equations we get \(y = 5(1) -3 = 2\). So we have solved the equations successfully using matrices above.
